title: 114_s156
content: The "Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2015" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Key definitions are provided in Section 2. The "Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2015" defines key terms such as Administrator, direct costs, and energy-related rule costing over $1 billion. The "Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2015" defines terms like indirect costs, rule, and Secretary of Energy. The "Energy Consumers Relief Act of 2015" prohibits finalizing energy-related rules costing over $1 billion if they will harm the economy. Reports and determinations are required before finalizing certain energy-related rules. Before finalizing any energy-related rule estimated to cost over $1 billion, the Administrator must submit a report to Congress and the Secretary detailing the rule, its costs, benefits, and expected realization timeline. The Administrator must provide a report to Congress and the Secretary before finalizing any energy-related rule costing over $1 billion. The report should include calculations, assumptions, limitations, and a certification that all data and documents used by the EPA are available for public review on their website. Additionally, it should contain an estimate of the energy price increases. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant agencies, will analyze the potential impacts of the rule, including energy price increases for consumers and employment effects such as job losses. The Secretary will analyze the potential impacts of the rule, including effects on low-income households, small businesses, manufacturers, fuel diversity, electric reliability, energy supply, distribution, and use. If adverse effects on the economy are determined, consultation with relevant agencies will be conducted. The Secretary, in consultation with relevant agencies, will determine if a rule will have significant adverse effects on the economy by considering costs, benefits, and impacts on economic indicators. The Secretary will determine the impact of a rule on the economy and publish the results in the Federal Register. PROHIBITION ON USE OF SOCIAL COST OF CARBON IN ANALYSIS. The social cost of carbon is defined as the monetized damages associated with an increase in carbon dioxide emissions. The Administrator is prohibited from using the social cost of carbon in analysis. The Administrator is restricted from using the social cost of carbon in any cost-benefit analysis for energy-related rules costing over $1 billion, unless authorized by Federal law.
